metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
April 20, 1944
102
Dear Gertie,
Your letter arrived describing your luncheon with
the Beligian Ambassador. It sounded to me that as old as you
are you were still a little out of your class if all the men
were your grand fathers confidants. What amazed me the most
was the description of the menu. How in the world do they
manage to give those banquets when the rest of the country is
struggling along on ration points and counting on their fingers
the number of months that must pass before they will be able to
have meat or butter again. However as long as you are asked
to these feasts it is alright. The time to complain ls when
they forget to"request your presence".
I know exactly how you feel when the first buds
come out on the trees. There is no torture so great as to have
to go into a gloomy office building, turn on the light and sit
down at a desk piled high with papers that have lost what little
they might have originally had before you saw the bud. Here
fortunately it is always spring. There are not any seasons.
Summer is hotter than winter by perhaps three or five degrees,
but otherwise there is nothing to indicate to a new arrival
the time of the year. The same flowers appear to be blooming,
the mountains are always green and covered with mist in une early
morning, and latxxer the sky becomes one immense canopy of
light, sun drenched blue and the day is under way. But to
show you how much places are a matter of the mind, Armant does
not like it here. He thinks the climate is damp and says he xx
feels enervated and tired as a result. To him it is no better if
not worse than New Orleans. I admit that you always feel tired
here but what ofit. Can you imagine a more beautiful place to
be tired in, and as mans lot is to be born tired I can ask for
no more. 
I am now growing really fat as three weeks have passed
and my cracked ribs have not healed. As a result the doctor says
that I must give up even the gentlest forms of exercise such as
sneezing and blowing my nose hard and remain absolutely quiet.
They were supposed to have been well at the end of dares weeks
and instead they hut more than the day when I broke them. It makes
me furious not to be able to go swimming or play tennis etc. when
they are at my door. One deos not mind quite so much when these
sports are unavaible, but when they are within easy reach it is
a different situatition. I took Armant to my Lady Oesteopath and
he calls her the little old lady and lives by what she tells him
to do. I believe if she gave the order to march into the sea she
would have her command obeyed. Morris looks on the whole matter
with great disdain and I am not sure that he is not the cleverest.
I think we are maybe the subjects, willing I grant, of a doctor
[End Page 1]
who treats her profession as a business and likes nice steady
customers just like a grocery store does.
The apartment is making no headway whatsoever as far
as being decorated is concerned. The curtains that were ordered
were never made because the store discovered to its suprise that
it did not have the cloth after all. It had a sample but nothing
more. The man that was to make the big couch which is called
something that sounds like a hicky ay"just has not got around to
it". The wall in Morrises room still has its big blotch of paint,
The painter who painted the living room and with whom we had
a fight, or rather Morris had a small discussion because he agreed
to pay him by the day and the days were very long, has left his
paints and brushed in the middle of the room. The old women who
lived in the mountains amd who came down from her hermitage
especially to weave us a mat cheaper than anyone else has left
after weaving a mat that is to small and whose edge[s]look like a
path left by a drunken serpent. The cook however that we snared
into our lair by giving her the best apartment in the buildling and
several thousand dollars a month is wonderful. She is a tiny
little Japanese girl who lives with her husband just below us.
She keeps everything spotless and moves around so quickly that
there is only a blur of light to be seen. She is also I THINK
a wonderful cook but has been held down somewhat by Morris insist-
ing that all we have eaten in our lives and all we wish to eat
is rice and potaotes. Armant says he is getting fatter and fatter
and hungrier and hungrier on this diet. But then he is a weakling
and not worthy of our sympathy.
I understand your big Boss went through herebut at the time
I did not see or hear of him. Only after he left did we receive
a letter saying,he was comming. But that is how I like things to
happen. It places everything in its true light and importance.
It really did not matter whether he came or not as far as the
great rank and file were cXoncerned. Had he tunred up it would
have meant that we would all have had to salute and stop working.
News to give you is such a rarity that whenever an item a small
morsel passes me I snatch itwith huhgry hands. The last few days
have unfortunately been very poor and my catch is not only meagre
but non existing. I have seen no one, heard nothing either
good or evil and done nothing. All our interest are fixed on
the comming invasion and our pray[er] is that we will do better than
we have been doing in Itatly. Even the military magazines admit
that we are doing terribly there. I guess the trade school
boys have sort of fallen down on us. I suppose that with the
conquest of Europe you will be without a job in that theatre, or
will your organisation out its members into cloaks and masks and
send you into the bars and bistros to gather information. If the
latter is the case be certain to let me know in order that
I may apply for duty with you.
I sned you all my love darling,
Sidney J. Legendre
